Technical assistance level cooperation with the Port Control Unit (PCU) in Montenegro has been continued yet impacted by the travel restrictions and other COVID-19 related challenges.

The effectiveness of the border law enforcement agencies consisting of the inter-agency PCU at the Port of Bar has been particularly supported through online and in-person mentorship visits, advance Strategic Trade and Export Control Training-joint event with the PCU Bijaca, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as procurement of the Information Technology (IT) and other basic equipment and tools for the PCU Bar.

2022 Narrative: The UNODC-WCO Container Control Programme (CCP) facilitated a study visit to the Port of Piraeus in Greece for 12 customs and police officers of the Port Control Unit (PCU) Bar, Montenegro, and the PCU Bijaca, Bosnia and Herzegovina. This study visit tackled all forms of trafficking and provided the necessary capacity building for the PCUs and customs and police administrations in the South Eastern European (SEE) region to combat this threat. During the three-day study visit, the Greek customs and police officers provided insight into their work at the Port of Piraeus to their counterparts from Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina who had an opportunity to see the x-ray scanners used in the Port and their operation, in addition to the physical inspection of containers by specially trained dogs. Furthermore, the CCP conducted a mentoring visit to the Port Control Unit (PCU) at the Port of Bar, Montenegro, to support the PCU officers in further enhancing their personal and organizational capacities to face the challenges occurring in the containerized trade supply chain. The CCP continued the delivery of the Strategic Trade and Export Control Training (STECT) for frontline officers of the Port Control Unit (PCU) at the Port of Bar in Montenegro.

Gender marker narrative: A gender perspective is actively mainstreamed in all UNODC practices, policies and programmes. In contributing and supporting the efforts of Member States to respond to evolving security threats by promoting the rule of law, good governance, human rights and sustainable development, UNODC recognises and plans for the different needs, capacities and contributions of women, men, girls and boys. Understanding the interrelationship between gender and security threats and crime is vital to the overall effectiveness of any response. Applying a gender perspective to UNODC’s work involves being aware of the gendered dimensions of any activity, which requires analysis, information and consultations with both women and men. Ultimately integrating a gender perspective will result in a more balanced and representative approach, thus a more effective response in all of UNODC’s thematic areas of work.

Human rights marker narrative: UNODC uniquely works across all three pillars in its efforts against crime, illicit drugs and terrorism and in supporting Member States to deliver a safe society founded on the rule of law. Bearing in mind the centrality of human rights to the aims of the UN, UNODC maximizes the positive human rights impact of its work and always takes a human rights perspective into account while planning programmes. A large number of rights contained in the international human rights treaties are also cross-cutting and relevant to UNODC mandates, including in the broad area of law enforcement. All UNODC technical assistance programmes’ policies aim at the realization of human rights. Human rights standards and principles guide development cooperation and programming in all sectors and in all phases of the programming process.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNODC organized activities related to corruption Trafficking in Persons (TiP), anti-money laundering, detection of firearms, and border management.  Regarding anti-corruption, UNODC carried out multiple initiatives and trainings at the request of and in consultation with the Ukrainian National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) and in collaboration with the UNODC Corruption and Economic Crime Section. From November 13 to 15, 2023 in Kyiv Ukraine, UNODC organized the workshop on ‘Financial Investigations for the Effective Detection of Corruption and Tracing of Proceeds of Crime’ which brought together 28 detectives and analysts from NABU. The aim was to strengthen Ukraine's financial investigation capabilities, an essential tool in the effective fight against corruption. UNODC bolstered the anti-corruption capacity and expertise of the Agency for Restoration (Recovery/Reconstruction) with two experts who are imbedded in the Agency by delivering training to NABU investigators on financial investigations and asset recovery in the anti-corruption context. UNODC also facilitated international cooperation for SAPO through the Global Operational Network of Anti-Corruption Law Enforcement Officers. UNODC continued to provide support to the education sector together with USAID, through the translation into Ukrainian and roll-out of university modules on integrity, ethics and anti-corruption, which are part of the Global Resource for Anti-Corruption Education and Youth Empowerment (GRACE) initiative. UNODC also contributed to the 2023 rapid damages needs assessment (RDNA) led by the Government of Ukraine, World Bank, EU and UN. Moving forward, UNODC is building on the successes of its global private sector integrity programme by expanding this programme to Ukraine, which will be the largest country component of the global programme. Regarding Trafficking in Persons (TIP) in October 2023, UNODC organized bilateral and multilateral meetings in the Netherlands to exchange knowledge on emerging trends in Trafficking in Persons (TiP) with the National Police of Ukraine, Prosecutor General’s Office of Ukraine, Judges, State Border Guard Service, and the Centre for Combatting Trafficking in Persons of Moldova. In November 2023, UNODC also trained 33 participants in-person and 160 participants online from the National Police of Ukraine and Prosecutor General’s Office of Ukraine to identify cases and refer victims of trafficking in persons among Ukrainians, addressing identified risk and immediate needs. Discussions touched on the practical challenges and examples of how to carry out effective detection, investigation and prosecution during the war. In terms of support to firerms control, UNODC developed training materials for Ukrainian Railways with firearms images and x-ray images for Ukrainian Railways of Ukraine. In November 2023, UNODC procured software licenses and equipment (15 PCs, 15 monitors, 1 display, 1 mobile stand, 1 laptop, and 1 walk-through detector) for computer-based training on firearms. Additionally, UNODC delivered training on the detection of firearms misuse through analyses of firearms x-rays images for Ukrainian Railways and inaugurated a training room at Ukranian Railways. UNODC also supported the Ministry of Internal Affairs in implementing the Unified Weapons Registry (UWR) in Ukraine. The UWR is a preventive measure outlined in Article 7 of the UN Firearms Protocol, aiming to maintain information on firearms to aid in tracing and identifying illicitly manufactured or trafficked firearms.On border management, in July 2023, UNODC conducted an assessment mission on Ukraine’s Border Control Points for the Ministry of Communities, Territories and Infrastructure Development and State Agency for Restoration and Development Infrastructure of Ukraine along with a validation meeting of findings in November 2023. UNODC also organized Study Visits for Ukrainian Customs officers to Japan and Turkey as well as a regional event in Istanbul on the National Targeting Centre. In December 2023, UNODC developed SOPs for simplified Customs clearance processes to facilitate legitimate trade at Boryspil Airport and the Port of Odessa. With reference to anti-money laundering (AML) efforts, UNODC supported the development of a training curriculum for Ukraine’s Financial Monitoring Service over four workstreams on AML through briefing and planning meetings, reviewing lesson materials, and practicing each course as well as advanced training on virtual assets investigations with Ukraine’s Financial Monitoring Service, Cyber police, National Bank of Ukraine, National Securities and Stock Market Commission, Ministry of Digital Transformation, National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine, Security Service of Ukraine, and State Bureau of Investigation. With reference to the Penitentiary System, in June 2023, UNODC held an international penitentiary forum in Kyiv with the Ministry of Justice and State Penitentiary Service of Ukraine. This forum helped raise awareness and fostered a shared understanding of the importance of the Nelson Mandela rules in ensuring the rights and well-being of prisoners UNODC also organized a Study Visit of seven officials form the Ministry of Justice to Croatia with a thematic focus on prisons and probation management. In October 2023, UNODC completed the translation of the UN Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners and the corresponding e-learning course. UNODC also participated, alongside the Ukrainian State Penitentiary Service, in the annual conference in Brussels of the International Corrections and Prisons Association (ICPA), where more than 800 participants from 79 countries pooled their knowledge and experience to discuss the latest developments in the field.
2024 Narrative: Anti-CorruptionUkraine resumed its country review under the second cycle of the Implementation Review Mechanism of the UN Convention against Corruption and held a self-assessment checklist workshop, focusing on prevention and asset recovery.As part of the Global Action for Business Integrity project funded by the Siemens Business Integrity Initiative, UNODC provides guidance to companies to adopt and implement strong anti-corruption systems. This includes trainings on public procurement and anti-corruption, a legal gap analysis and support for the new model code of conduct for Ukrainian companies.Border Management:UNODC conducted a border crossing point assessment as well as a needs assessment to enhance cross-border crime prevention of border management authorities. Border management projects focused on enhancing technical capability of border control, aiming at disrupting illicit flows of goods. This includes the establishment of port control units at seaports and land borders crossings.Organized Crime Strategy:UNODC launched a new project to develop Ukraine’s national strategy on organized crime. With support from the United Kingdom, UNODC started to provide guidance to the country-led process, including through stakeholder consultations, awareness raising campaigns and a study visit for a Ukrainian delegation to the United Kingdom, to exchange on best practices for organized crime threat assessments as the baseline for comprehensive and evidence-based strategies.Trafficking in Persons  Conflict-Related Sexual Violence:UNODC provided support to law enforcement officials, prosecutors and the judiciary to strengthen national and community-based conflict-related sexual violence prevention. In this work, UNODC applied a survivor-centered multi-sectoral approach, targeting rights-based investigations and prosecutions, enhanced witness protection and exchange of best practices of legal and regulatory frameworks.Anti-Money Laundering:UNODC provided technical equipment and software to the State Financial Monitoring Service with the aim to support AML investigations. Furthermore, UNODC supported authorities to coordinate and deliver inter-agency training on AML to national competent authorities.Firearms:UNODC supported Ukrainian authorities to enhance detection of firearms trafficking and to strengthen investigations including through identification of firearms, x-ray analysis, and investigative measures including forensics. UNODC provided support to Ukrainian Railways on weapons detection as a measure to counteract trafficking of firearms. Prison Reform:As part of a project on penitentiary reform, UNODC is providing technical assistance on crisis preparedness, adult learning, rehabilitation and social reintegration, as well as managing prisoners with special needs. The project also delivered equipment to enhance operational capacity.

2022 Narrative: The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) Regional Programme for South Eastern Europe Programme Office in North Macedonia, in conjunction with the Global Programme against Money-Laundering, Proceeds of Crime and the Financing of Terrorism (GPML), is running the AML/CFT Court Preparation project (the Project).  The project aims to assist the Member States to more effectively investigate, arrest, prosecute, convict and disrupt terrorists, terrorist networks and organized crime groups. Throughout the course, participants are trained using localised scenarios reflecting the issues that would typically arise in that jurisdiction. Course materials also incorporate the domestic legislative framework used when prosecuting and seeking convictions of terrorists and terrorist networks. 10-12 prosecutors from the Prosecutor’s office for organized crime and corruption and judges from the Basic Criminal Court for Organized Crime and Corruption are participating in the Project. The AML/CFT Court Preparation project takes participants through their AML/CFT law and the elements of their AML/CFT offence with the overall aim of assisting judges and prosecutors to prepare sound case files linking the elements of the offence to the alleged conduct and evidence. Consequently, prosecutors should be better able to establish money laundering and terrorist financing offences in court and judges will be better equipped to adjudicate such cases.
2023 Narrative: 10 participants gained advanced skills in preparing for court proceedings, focusing on building a case, developing a case theory, and understanding the threshold and reliability of evidence, including insights from European court decisions. 10 Judges and prosecutors acquired specialized knowledge in the areas of money laundering (ML) and terrorist financing (TF), including understanding international standards related to minimal evidence in ML cases.Participants gained insights into the significance of financial investigation as a crucial tool in the fight against terrorism. This knowledge enhances their ability to contribute effectively to counterterrorism efforts.In summary, the completion of the programme intervention resulted in a substantial augmentation of skills, a deepening of specialized knowledge, and an increased capacity to apply these skills in real-world scenarios for the participants from the Public Prosecutor’s Office for Organized Crime and Corruption and Basic Public Court. These acquired capabilities contribute significantly to their roles in combating organized crime and corruption, particularly in the realms of financial crimes and counterterrorism.

Gender marker narrative: The project will effectively mainstream gender and promote and support gender equality and girls’ and women’s empowerment, and, also in line with the EU gender equality strategy 2020-2025, the gender perspective and gender responsive justice and rights-based services will be systematically included in design and implementation of activities and policies.  The project will be guided by the EU Gender Action Plan III and the Women, Peace and Security (WPS) agenda, formally initiated by the landmark UN Security Council Resolution 1325 (2000), adopted on 31 October 2000. The WPS agenda affirms the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peace-building initiatives. It rests on four pillars: prevention, participation, protection and relief and recovery. It focuses on the links between gender inequality and conflict, how they are mutually reinforcing, and emphasizes the need to understand gender inequality as a root cause and driver of conflict and fragility. The project will be in line with the pillar 3 of the EU Gender Action Plan III and specific measures of policy 3.5: Integrating the women, peace and security agenda: promoting and supporting inclusive policies/activities across the whole WPS agenda with full and equitable participation, also by men and boys; promoting the strengthening of the rule of law, the criminal justice system through transitional and restorative justice, and Security Sector Reform (SSR), to end impunity for perpetrators of SGBV crimes; promoting the provision of medical, psycho-social, legal and safety support to all victims/survivors of conflict-related sexual and/or gender-based violence/SGBV.  The project will follow the UNDP gender equality strategy 2022-2025 and the objective of achieving gender justice to realize rights. Hence, with UN Women and Gender Justice Platform, UNDP will provide continued technical, financial and policy support on link between gender equality and legal protection, gender responsive justice, security sector reforms, legal aid services, transitional justice and constitutional reforms. The main obstacles for achieving gender equality are deeply rooted in patriarchal norms, as well as in the lack of systemic solutions for persistent implementation of polices for achieving gender equality. These patriarchal patterns affect women deeply. It is fair to say that the legacies of the conflicts present huge obstacle in building just, equal societies, respectful of human rights and gender equality principles. Consequences of wars, conflict and economic decline affect women and men differently.    Women in the region have been specifically and deeply affected by these conflicts. Precise gender-disaggregated data on victims and survivors of the conflicts have not been part of information available from the prosecution offices or the courts, or reliable data on human losses and toll of war crimes victims, but a large part of the overall number of war crimes victims and survivors are women. They were most notably struck as the survivors of conflict-related sexual violence (CRSV) crimes.
